newsitem.title: INDIA: India Morgan Stanley fund tightens portfolio.
newsitem.headline: India Morgan Stanley fund tightens portfolio.

text.p: Morgan Stanley Growth Fund, India's largest private sector mutual fund, has tightened its portfolio stocks to improve prospects, the fund said on Tuesday.

"We have reduced the number of holdings and increased concentration levels in the portfolio to the point where the top 50 holdings now account for nearly 75 percent of the total value of the fund," fund manager Akash Prakash said in a report.
The fund had a corpus of 8.06 billion rupees as on June 13, 1997 compared to 9.81 billion when it was launched in January, 1994, an official said.
During the period, the net asset value of the fund dropped five percent against a 16.4 percent fall in the Bombay Stock Exchange 200-share index, the report said.

"We believe that this restructuring exercise will allow the fund to benefit from improved market environment in the medium-term and will allow the fund to provide superior investment performance over its 15 year life," Prakash said.
The fund's top 10 holdings account for 60.4 percent of the portfolio against 28.2 percent previously, the report said.

"We have worked towards changing the profile of companies in the portfolio to focus on those companies we believe have the management capabilities and competitive position to benefit from the post-liberalisation Indian economy," it said.

Its top 10 holdings are: Bharat Heavy Electricals Ltd, Container Corporation of India Ltd, Housing Development Finance Corp Ltd, State Bank of India, Infosys Technologies Ltd, MRF Ltd, Sundaram Finance Ltd, Asahi India Safety Glass, CIPLA Ltd and HDFC Bank.
There are 1.32 million investors in the fund.
